channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: A bitter dispute between China and Japan has moved to the cultural front
item.description: A bitter dispute between East Asia's biggest powers, China and Japan, has moved to the cultural front. With both sides unwilling to back down, experts say it could be a protracted feud.
item.content:encoded: A bitter dispute between East Asia's biggest powers, China and Japan, has moved to the cultural front. With both sides unwilling to back down, experts say it could be a protracted feud.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Kuhn

item.title: The Trump administration fires at least 7 immigration judges in New York
item.description: The Trump administration fired immigration judges in New York on Monday. NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with Jeremiah Johnson Executive Vice President of the National Association of Immigration Judges.
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration fired immigration judges in New York on Monday. NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with Jeremiah Johnson Executive Vice President of the National Association of Immigration Judges.
item.dc:creator: Ailsa Chang

item.title: Remembering Dorothy Vogel, who collected art with her husband on civil servant salaries
item.description: Librarian Dorothy Vogel, who, with her late husband Herb, amassed a priceless collection of contemporary art in their one bedroom apartment, died on Nov. 10.
item.content:encoded: Librarian Dorothy Vogel, who, with her late husband Herb, amassed a priceless collection of contemporary art in their one bedroom apartment, died on Nov. 10.

item.title: ICE raids have deterred foreign farm workers, but farmers hope to make hiring easier
item.description: U.S. farms increasingly depend on foreign workers, but ICE raids have exacerbated the agriculture labor crisis. Some farmers want to make it easier to hire people from abroad using a visa program.
item.content:encoded: U.S. farms increasingly depend on foreign workers, but ICE raids have exacerbated the agriculture labor crisis. Some farmers want to make it easier to hire people from abroad using a visa program.
item.dc:creator: Frank Morris

item.title: What we know about Russia-Ukraine peace talks at the Kremlin
item.description: U.S. envoys Jared Kushner and Steve Witkoff visit Moscow to present the Ukraine peace proposal.
item.content:encoded: U.S. envoys Jared Kushner and Steve Witkoff visit Moscow to present the Ukraine peace proposal.
item.dc:creator: Charles Maynes

item.title: Firms that help military vets with their disability claims can charge exorbitant fees
item.description: NPR has been following the money behind veterans' disability claims — specifically, for-profit companies that help vets navigate the VA's red tape. Critics of the companies call them "claim sharks."
item.content:encoded: NPR has been following the money behind veterans' disability claims — specifically, for-profit companies that help vets navigate the VA's red tape. Critics of the companies call them "claim sharks."
item.dc:creator: Quil Lawrence

item.title: An artist makes tiny suits of armor for mice
item.description: Calgary artist Jeff De Boer has spent decades learning, perfecting, and teaching the art of making suits of armor. For mice.
item.content:encoded: Calgary artist Jeff De Boer has spent decades learning, perfecting, and teaching the art of making suits of armor. For mice.
item.dc:creator: Deena Prichep

item.title: In Trump country, attention turns to a competitive special election
item.description: A special election in what should be a safe seat for Republicans has proven to be more competitive than expected as polls close Tuesday.
item.content:encoded: A special election in what should be a safe seat for Republicans has proven to be more competitive than expected as polls close Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Marianna Bacallao

item.title: The story of two sisters was a standout in the NPR College Podcast Challenge
item.description: A standout entry from our NPR College Podcast Challenge was a story about two sisters: One a college junior, the other a soldier in the U.S. Army.
item.content:encoded: A standout entry from our NPR College Podcast Challenge was a story about two sisters: One a college junior, the other a soldier in the U.S. Army.
item.dc:creator: Trinity Chase Hunt

item.title: Serious questions remain about September strike on suspected drug traffickers
item.description: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth defends his role in a military strike against suspected drug traffickers in the Carribbean. Members of Congress are demanding more answers.
item.content:encoded: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth defends his role in a military strike against suspected drug traffickers in the Carribbean. Members of Congress are demanding more answers.
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre
